channel.title: Muay Thai
channel.description:
I am beginning lessons on Muay Thai fighting styles this weekend.
Does anyone else take any lessons on it?
How does it rank in your mind against other fighting styles and martial arts?

item.title: Muay Thai
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“the bank, post:14, topic:256592”][quote author=dragonfire455 link=topic=338906.msg2659350#msg2659350 date=1234082309]

[quote author=Yz85Racer link=topic=338906.msg2659170#msg2659170 date=1234069592]

I’m taking lessons in Wing Chung Kung Fu but you have to remember every martial art has it’s weaknesses and strengths. Muay Thai is pretty good though.

That’s why relying on one martial art is stupid. Learn a Stand & Trade martial art (i.e Muay Thai), a Stand -> Ground martial art (i.e Judo) and a Ground work martial art (i.e Jiu-jitsu, Wrestling (not really a martial art, but uno)).
[/quote]I am, personally I dislike brazillian jujitsu because it’s based on 1 and 1 combat. In real life you’ll never encounter that because people will always have their “possies” or friends to back them up in a fight. I like the idea of learning judo though. I’ll keep that in mind.
[/quote]It is foolish to fight more than one person at once.

Even in a large fight, focus on one person at a time. If you focus on the whole group, you will lose.[/quote]
gl finding a martial art that focuses on fighting more than one person on the ground.

Read full topic

I’m taking lessons in Wing Chung Kung Fu but you have to remember every martial art has it’s weaknesses and strengths. Muay Thai is pretty good though.

That’s why relying on one martial art is stupid. Learn a Stand & Trade martial art (i.e Muay Thai), a Stand -> Ground martial art (i.e Judo) and a Ground work martial art (i.e Jiu-jitsu, Wrestling (not really a martial art, but uno)).
[/quote]I am, personally I dislike brazillian jujitsu because it’s based on 1 and 1 combat. In real life you’ll never encounter that because people will always have their “possies” or friends to back them up in a fight. I like the idea of learning judo though. I’ll keep that in mind.[/quote]It is foolish to fight more than one person at once.

Even in a large fight, focus on one person at a time. If you focus on the whole group, you will lose.

item.title: Muay Thai
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“Ske, post:7, topic:256592”]I’ve taken a few lessons too and i gotta tell you it’s really hard.
I was already tired when i did the warm up

anyway, in my opinion it’s the best fighting style when you just want to learn to fight without knowing those fancy karate moves.[/quote]
Mixed Martial Arts would be better if you don’t want to learn “fancy moves”.

Read full topic

anyway, in my opinion it’s the best fighting style when you just want to learn to fight without knowing those fancy karate moves.

item.title: Muay Thai
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

io9:

Yz85Racer takes Muay Thai.

ya !!!

Yeah, I do Muay Thai. It’s alright, it’s great fun to train in, but fighting sucks. Getting kneed in the face has made me reconsider, it hurts like fuck. I’m quite happy with Jiu-jitsu

Read full topic
